Award.AwardTitle: Global Distributions of Ultra-Low Frequency (ULF) Wave Power in the Quiet Magnetosphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ultra-Low Frequency (ULF) waves are a common feature in Earth's magnetosphere. They are thought to play important roles in the formation of the radiation belts and the formation of the magnetospheric ring current that causes strong suppression of the magnetic field on the ground during magnetic storms. The waves may also play a role in such phenomena as magnetospheric substorms, sawtooth events, and steady magnetospheric convection. A key to understanding the variability of the intensities and types of ULF waves is understanding the baseline condition of the magnetosphere during magnetically quiet times. In addition to enhancing our understanding of the baseline state of the magnetosphere this project will also have significant educational benefits. The research will include a number of undergraduate students and the work will closely integrate the research being done with the education of the students.

The most recent sunspot minimum was an unusually quiet period that was marked by extended intervals during which the magnetosphere was in a quiet, steady state. While much prior research has been done on ULF waves during magnetically disturbed times, surprisingly little is known about the distribution of ULF waves during quiet times. This project will investigate the role the solar wind plays in the generation of ULF waves during the recent sunspot minimum when the magnetosphere was unusually quiet. It will develop statistical maps of the compressional and toroidal wave power in various frequency bands as a function of location in the magnetosphere and the solar wind and interplanetary magnetic field parameters. The statistical maps will be developed using ground-based magnetometers as well as data from the European Cluster satellite mission and the NASA THEMIS mission.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was an investigation of the dayside distribution of Pc5 wave power in the quiet magnetosphere (defined as 10 > Dst > -20 nT) and its response to the solar wind. We compiled a set of over 400,000 data points using THEMIS magnetic field data for our plots of dayside Pc5 compressional and transverse wave power. The solar wind properties considered were bulk velocity V, dynamic pressure P, and fluctuations in the dynamic pressure Pvar.

Findings

  1. The compressional and transverse power enhancements associated with the three solar wind properties were comparable and were observed to a depth within the magnetosphere of about L = 5.
  2. Power plots based on the combined effects of the dynamic pressure P, which controls the position of the magnetopause, and the bulk velocity V, the mechanism behind the KHI-driven waves on the magnetopause, reflected the solar wind dynamic pressure control of the magnetopause location. This effect is shown in Fig. 1 for compressional Pc5 power. Comparative plots of the Pc5 compressional power distribution are made between high and low V (solid and dashed lines respectively) during intervals with low P [panel (a)] and between high and low V during intervals with high P [panel (b)]. The black, blue, and red lines correspond to the noon, morning and afternoon sectors. When the spacecraft-magnetopause distance is reduced by high P, the KHI-driven surface waves can be observed to about L = 5. In contrast, the observed penetration of the waves into the magnetosphere ends between L = 6.5 and 7 for low P. The amplitude of the KHI-driven waves is also significantly higher throughout the outer magnetosphere during intervals of high P. Finally, even for low V, there is enhanced wave activity at L = 9 for intervals of high P due to spacecraft proximity to the magnetopause.
  3. A comparison of the Pc5 power response to V and Pvar showed that the greater power enhancement was associated with V in the outer magnetosphere beyond L ~ 6 but with Pvar at distances farther from the magnetopause and closer to Earth. This effect is shown in Fig. 2 for both compressional [panel (a)] and transverse [panel (b)] Pc5 wave power. Our entire database is first divided into three equal bins of high, intermediate, and low values of Pvar. Within the low-value bin, we select the lowest third of the values of V. The L-dependence of compressional Pc5 power associated with these points (low V, low Pvar) is plotted as our reference baseline (black line). Within the low-value Pvar bin, we also select the highest third of the values of V. The power associated with these points (high V, low Pvar) is plotted as the red line. Finally, within the high-value Pvar bin, we select the lowest third of the values of V. The power associated with these points (low V, high Pvar) is plotted as the blue line. In comparing the Pc5 power levels of the red line (high V, low Pvar) and the blue line (low V, high Pvar) with the baseline, we see that in the vicinity of the magnetopause, the power enhancement associated with V (KHI-driven waves) is dominant. Within the magnetosphere away from the magnetopause, the power enhancement associated with Pvar (radial fast mode waves) increases at a greater rate until at about L = 6, Pc5 wave power is equally enhanced by the two solar wind parameters. For L < 6, a greater enhancement is observed for Pvar.

These findings are detailed in a paper that was submitted to Planetary and Space Science earlier this year:

Dayside distribution of Pc5 wave power in the quiet magnetosphere and its response to the solar wind; David Berube, Jeff Sanny, Rhys Taus, and Alexander Garoutte (Physics Department, Loyola Marymount University, Los Angeles, California, USA)
